1 Jira Concepts

Iterative approach to development. Planning the iteration. Delivering a part of the product before it is complete. Changes are fed in to the next iteration. There should be a shippable product. Customers see features coming through. Requirements are met more quickly. Documentation is kept to a minimum.

1.1 Scrum

Break projects in to epics and stories. A user story is the smallest unit of work. User stories are prioritized.

Development is performed in short cycles, known as Sprints. You start with a backlog.

  • backlog
  • Sprint backlog
  • 2-4 weeks (a sprint)
  • daily scrum meeting
  • release

1.1.1 Roles

  • product owner
    • defines the vision of the product
    • what should be built and why
  • dev team
    • builds the product
  • scrum master
    • facilitates the scrum process

1.1.2 Scrum events

  • Sprint planning
    • sprint backlog created from product backlog
    • dev team provides estimates - story points or hours
  • daily scrum
    • what i did yesterday
    • what do i plan to do today
    • do i have any blockers?
  • Sprint Review and Retrospective
    • Review - what was completed/not completed?
    • Retro - what went well during sprint and what could be improved for next sprint?

1.2 Kanban

Simpler. Define work flow. Kanban board - visualize the workflow. Limit work in progress items. Monitor, adapt and improve.

Better for unpredictable development.

1.3 Jira Terms

A ticket is an issue (of a different issue type). A project is exactly what you'd think. Workflow is set of statuses that the issue can have. Versions are a shippable product. Components are a category of work. Other common agile terms.

2 Jira Administration

2.1 User Management

2.1.1 Types of Admin

Site admins - gets the site admin privileges. Jira administrators - not the site admin. Jira admin can access all the settings. Administrator settings gives admin rights under all applications in the instance installed (e.g. confluence too). Custom group.

When you create an external user, you should remove them from the jira-software-users group as that is the default and is wide open.

2.1.2 Give the Group Permissions

This is through Product Access page. Add a group to the product access page. That gives that group product access, which means they can see stuff (the same as jira-software-users). You need to refresh the page to see that

2.2 Permissions

2.2.1 Permission Levels

User is part of a group which can be given Global Permissions, and/or Project Permissions.

  1. Global Permissions

    Apply to the install.

    These are found under settings, System, Global Permissions.

    • Administer Jira
    • Browse Users and groups
    • Share dashboards and filters
    • Manage group filter subscriptions
    • Make bulk changes
    • Create next-gen projects
    1. Administer Jira

      This is the one that will admin jira. Ignore system-administrators and atlassian-addons-admin. trusted-users group is there.

      Go to the admin page, and it takes you to Product Access.

    2. Browse User and groups

      View and select users or groups from the user picker, and share issues. Users with this permission can see the names of all users and groups on your site.

    3. Share dashboards and filters

      Share dashboards and filters with other users.

    4. Manage group filter subscriptions

      Create and delete group filter subscriptions.

    5. Make bulk changes

      Modify collections of issues at once. For example, resolve multiple issues in one step.

    6. Create next-gen projects

      Create projects separate from shared configurations and schemes. Next-gen projects don't affect existing projects or shared configurations like workflows, fields or permissions. Only licensed users can create next-gen projects.

    7. How do you give these permissions?

      At the bottom of the screen, you can have a Grant Permission.

  2. Project Permissions

    Apply to only the project. Groups are given a Permission Scheme that helps them with their project. A single permission scheme can be assigned to multiple projects, but each project can only have one permission scheme defined for it.

    You can see the permission scheme applied to a project by going to the project, clicking on settings and then looking at the permissions tab.

    You can create a new permission scheme and assign it to multiple projects.

    Go back to settings, under issues, there is permission schemes. You change who gets what action.

    You want UserA to create issues is project A only and UserB to create issues only in project B.

    For this scenario, you will need to create two different permission schemes.

    This is now becoming unmanageable. Jira allowed for project roles. You can define project roles, so it applies to all of jira. Every project you create has access to these roles. You take users and assign them to the project roles. The project roles get assigned to the project.

    1. Project Roles

      This is found under the System settings, under the security heading. You can make default members. You can assign it within the project settings, under the people section.

      The roles are attached to a permission scheme. If the role does not do what the user expects, instead of changing the permission scheme, you should check that they are in the correct role. Each project has its own project role(s).

      You could create a role called "Issue Creator" - if you do, all projects in jira allow for that. Then you create a Permission Role and attach it to the role.

    2. Where Do Groups Fit in to this?

      Groups should be added to project roles. We add a group to a project role, then a role has actions via the permission scheme and the roles in the project allow for that permission to be used only in that project.

      Groups –> Project Role -—> Permission scheme 1 ----–—> Project 1 ­–> Permission scheme 2 – ­–> Project 2 ­–—> Project 3

      Add users to a project and give them the Role that you created (in this case Issue Creator. Then go to Settings, and then issues, then Permission schemes.

      Then, click Permissions for the project, find the permission you need. Then Edit, then choose the role that you want to apply the permission to.

      When that user hits create issue and then chooses projects from the drop-down, they will only see the projects that they have access for.

      More advantages of Project Roles, using groups is unmanageable. Whereas, using project roles is easier. Only jira admins can add users to groups. Project roles - the project admin can do that. This is something they can do.

      How much work will this take?

      *

  3. Permission Examples

    Create new project. Create a consultant user. This user should only have access to this project alone, and no other projects in your instance. This user should also have the ability to work on issues in the 'Permissios Example Project'.

    Create a 'custom' user. This user should have access to this project alone, and no other projects in your instance. This user should have read-only access in the project.

    Create a 'Project Owner' user who can administer the project and is the only one who can manage sprints.

    Developer user can work on issues.

    Solution: Create users - consultant, customer, project owner and developer. Create the groups - consultant, customer. Create the project roles based on the users and groups that are created - consultant, developer, customer, and project owner. Create a new permission scheme for the project and assign the individual project permissions to the respective project roles that were just created Create the new project.

    It's best to create the project last as this picks up anything new that has been created (older projects won't get them). You need to go in and manually assign roles to projects if the project was created first.

    Update the project to use the new permission scheme that was created. Assign the respective users and groups to each of the project roles for that project. Then, log in as each user and ensure everything works as configured.

    If you copy a permission scheme to create a new one it might take more time, rather than just starting off with a brand-clean one.

    When you create a new permission scheme, there are no permissions with it, or no projects with it.

    You can create a project role, called project team.

    By default, read-only is default.

    Groups are assigned to Project Roles when they are added. This is how they pick up their use.

3 Jira Schemes

3.1 Issue Types

Defaults are story, epic, etc. These are grouped together to a scheme.

We will create a new issue type called 'Spike'. This might be a feature request that is unknown. Add type to a project.

3.2 Fields

Custom fields. Fields can be configured and is mapped to an issue type.

We will create some custom fields and map them accordingly.

3.3 Screens

Fields are shown on a screen. This becomes a screen scheme, which is in turn mapped to a project.

We will create a screen for the new issue type and mapp it to the screen scheme with create/edit/view and mapp that issue types through the issue type screen scheme.

3.4 Workflows

Create your own workflow. This becomes a workflow scheme, which is the assigned to a project.

We will modify an existing workflow and then map these changes to that board. Create new workflow for the new issue type.

3.5 Project

All the above are linked to a project.

3.6 Configuration

These are all configured in the Issue tab in the settings for a project.

3.7 Create New Issue Type

Do not just rename them as it will confuse users. Add Issue Type.

Issue Type Schemes are created for each project that you create. Spike only goes into the default Issue Type Scheme to begin with. Existing projects do not pick it up.

When should you create a new issue type? When the work you're planning is not represented by the issue types already there. Also if this issue type needs a different type of workflow than those that already exist.

3.8 Create New Screen Schemes

Jira creates two new screen types (one for bugs and one for Default Issue Type for all other Issue types.

You can display screens for a workflow or for project. If you click on a screen, you get all the fields for that screen. All operations will default to this screen.

Issue Type Screen Schemes - you can map a screen scheme to an issue type.

For bugs, all unmapped operations use theh Bug Screen.

This will create a screen for when we create a spike, and another when we edit a spike.

It can be easier to copy screens. Copy them and give them a new name. They won't show up as they are not associated with projects yet.

Choose the fields for the new Screen.

Then create a new screen Scheme. You'll have to create one and choose the default screen. Then you have to map the Issue operation to a screen. This is in the top right hand corner of the next screen.

Then go to the Issue Type Screen Schemes. This is with the bug and default. We're going to add our new Spike Screen Scheme by clicking the associate link in the top right hand corner.

3.9 Create Custom Fields

This is bound within the Issues Settings for Jira. Within the advanced is the message custom field (for view) - this means we can display text on a screen.

You can select which screen you want to add the field to.

You can edit the context of a field. You can specify that this field is available for particular projects or particual issue types.

3.9.1 What about Mandatory Fields?

You don't want all fields to be mandatory for all screens.

This is carried out in the Field Configurations tab under Issues settings. There is a default config that is used by all projects.

Copy a field configuration and make the changes (e.g. making some fields required). Then you need to map it to an issue type.

To map a field configuration to an issue type, go to Field Configuration Schemes.

It appears that there are no configuration schemes, but there are, they are just hidden in the background.

Once you create one, you'll see that it is mapped to the Default Field Configuration scheme. You'll want to change that. So, you change the Association an issue type with a field configuration. Then go to the project and make sure it is using the new scheme. Go to the project. Click actions, then use a different scheme, then choose the new field scheme. In the project settings, click Fields, Actions, Use a different scheme, and in the drop down, choose the new scheme you created and then Associate.

Note: if you set a field to be mandatory, make sure it is set to appear on the screen. If it's not displayed, you won't be able to create the issue, as people can't set it as it's not on the screen.

4 Workflows

4.1 Creating new Workflows

Workflows control the flow of issues. This is a core feature of jira. You can transition from one status to another status.

When you create a workflow, initially it is inactive and needs assigning to a workflow scheme. Click on Workflow Schemes and edit the one that you need for that project. Then click Add Workflow, then choose the workflow you created, then next, then you can choose which Issue Type to associate it to. Then, back at the top page, click Publish.

This will now show up in the project settings workflow settings.

When you edit an existing workflow, you start off in draft. You don't want to edit a live one, but rather keep it in draft. When you publish, you get to keep a backup.

You can't make changes on a live workflow. You can't publish changes that are drastic to a live workflow. So, how do you do this? You make a workflow inactive first. Once a flow is inactive you can do anything to it without restrictions. You can replace the current one with a copy first, and then make it inactive and then change everything in it.

4.2 Adding new Status

If you change a status, you can change it for all projects and workflows. It's always safer not to modify an existing workflow, but create a new one or a copy instead.

You can enforce transitions by removing the all statuses. Code review can be a new status. You cannot add your own status category (and there are only three at the time of the video). 'To Do', 'In Progress' and 'Done'. You can create a status called 'Code Review' and 'Ready for Testing'. Then it can go to the 'In Testing' status. Then you create transitions to link them up.

You can transition backwards, to a previous state. A transition could be created called 'Back To Dev'.

Once you've finished, you should go back to the Workflow Schemes and add it back to the project (publish and associate are also needed).

Once the workflow is finished, you should modify the board to show this.

4.3 Updating Agile Board With New Workflow
